chunk.0: It is not always easy to distinguish clearly when one period ends and another begins. So, if we think of the history of modern India as beginning with the advent of the Europeans, we need to go back to what is generally considered the medieval period, i.e., the 15th century itself—indeed to a time even before the Mughals came and established their empire.
chunk.1: 21✫✫✫✫✫ 22 A Brief History of Modern India The Portuguese in India The Quest for and Discovery of a Sea Route to India After the decline of the Roman Empire in the 7th century, the Arabs had established their domination in Egypt and Persia. Direct contact between the Europeans and India declined, and, with that, the easy accessibility to the Indian commodities like spices, calicoes, silk, and various precious stones that were greatly in demand was affected. In 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottoman Turks, who were on the ascendant. Merchandise from India went to the European markets through Arab Muslim intermediaries.
chunk.2: In 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottoman Turks, who were on the ascendant. Merchandise from India went to the European markets through Arab Muslim intermediaries. The Red Sea trade route was a state monopoly from which Islamic rulers earned tremendous revenues. The land routes to India were also controlled by the Arabs. In the circumstances, the Europeans were keen to find a direct sea route to India. Fifteenth-century Europe was gripped by the spirit of the Renaissance with its call for exploration. At the same time, Europe made great advances in the art of ship-building and navigation.
chunk.3: At the same time, Europe made great advances in the art of ship-building and navigation. Hence, there was an eagerness all over Europe for adventurous sea voyages to reach the unknown corners of the East.The economic development of many regions of Europe was also progressing rapidly with expansion of land under cultivation, the introduction of an improved plough, scientific crop management such as crop rotation, and increased supply of meat (which called for spices for cooking as well as for preservation). Prosperity also grew, and with it the demand for oriental luxury goods also increased.
chunk.4: Prosperity also grew, and with it the demand for oriental luxury goods also increased. Venice and Genoa which had earlier prospered through trade in oriental goods were too small to take on the mighty Ottoman Turks or to take up major exploration on their own. The north Europeans were ready to aid Portugal and Spain with money and men, even as the Genoese were ready to provide ships and technical knowledge. It is also to be noted that Portugal had assumed the leadership in Christendom’s✫✫✫✫✫ Advent of the Europeans in India 23 resistance to Islam even as it had taken on itself the spirit of exploration that had characterised the Genoese.
chunk.5: Historians have observed that the idea of finding an ocean route to India had become an obsession for Prince Henry of Portugal, who was nicknamed the ‘Navigator’; also, he was keen to find a way to circumvent the Muslim domination of the eastern Mediterranean and all the routes that connected India to Europe. Pope Nicholas V gave Prince Henry a bull in 1454, conferring on him the right to navigate the “sea to the distant shores of the Orient”, more specifically “as far as India” in an attempt to fight Islamic influence and spread the Christian faith.
chunk.6: Pope Nicholas V gave Prince Henry a bull in 1454, conferring on him the right to navigate the “sea to the distant shores of the Orient”, more specifically “as far as India” in an attempt to fight Islamic influence and spread the Christian faith. However, Prince Henry died before his dream could become a reality. In 1497, under the Treaty of Tordesillas (1494), the rulers of Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them by an imaginary line in the Atlantic, some 1,300 miles west of the Cape Verde Islands. Under the treaty, Portugal could claim and occupy everything to the east of the line while Spain could claim everything to the west. The situation was thus prepared for the Portuguese incursions into the waters around India.
chunk.7: Under the treaty, Portugal could claim and occupy everything to the east of the line while Spain could claim everything to the west. The situation was thus prepared for the Portuguese incursions into the waters around India. It was in 1487 that the Portuguese navigator, Bartholomew Dias, rounded the Cape of Good Hope in Africa and sailed up the eastern coast; he was well convinced that the long-sought-after sea route to India had been found. But it was only ten years later that an expedition of Portuguese ships set out for India (in 1497) and arrived in India in slightly less than 11 months’ time, in May 1498.
chunk.8: From Trading to Ruling Vasco Da Gama The arrival of three ships under Vasco Da Gama, led by a Gujarati pilot named Abdul Majid, at Calicut in May 1498 profoundly affected the course of Indian history. The Hindu ruler of Calicut, the Zamorin (Samuthiri), however, had no apprehensions as to the European’s intentions. As the prosperity of his kingdom was due to Calicut’s position as an entrepot,✫✫✫✫✫ 24 A Brief History of Modern India he accorded a friendly reception to Vasco Da Gama. The Arab traders, who had a good business on the Malabar Coast were apprehensive and were not keen on the Portuguese getting a hold there.
chunk.9: The Arab traders, who had a good business on the Malabar Coast were apprehensive and were not keen on the Portuguese getting a hold there. For centuries, the trading system in the Indian Ocean had had numerous participants—Indians, Arabs, Africans from the east coast, Chinese, Javanese, among others—but these participants had acted according to some tacit rules of conduct and none had sought overwhelming dominance though all were in it for profit. The Portuguese changed that: they wanted to monopolise the hugely profitable eastern trade by excluding competitors, especially the Arabs. Vasco da Gama stayed in India for three months.

summary.0: History is a continuous flow and it can be difficult to separate one period from another. The modern history of India is said to have started with the arrival of Europeans. This takes us back to the 15th century, even before the Mughal Empire was established.
summary.1: To understand the history of modern India, we must go back to the 15th century, before the Mughals arrived. At this time, the Arabs dominated trade with India, but after the fall of Constantinople in 1453, European access to Indian goods was limited. Merchandise from India was sold to Europe through Arab Muslim intermediaries.
summary.2: After the fall of Constantinople in 1453, the Ottoman Turks gained power and controlled the Red Sea trade route, which was a major source of revenue for Islamic rulers. The Arabs also controlled the land routes to India, making it difficult for Europeans to access Indian commodities. In response, Europeans sought a direct sea route to India during the Renaissance, aided by advancements in ship-building and navigation.
summary.3: Europeans were eager to find a direct sea route to India as the land routes were controlled by Arab Muslim intermediaries. Ship-building and navigation advanced in Europe during the Renaissance, leading to an eagerness for adventurous sea voyages. Economic development and prosperity in Europe increased the demand for oriental luxury goods.
summary.4: As Europe developed, people became eager to explore the unknown corners of the East. They wanted spices for cooking and preservation, and the demand for luxury goods increased. Venice and Genoa were too small to explore on their own, but the north Europeans were ready to help Portugal and Spain with money and men. Portugal had taken on the spirit of exploration and leadership in resisting Islam.
summary.5: Prince Henry of Portugal, also known as the 'Navigator', was obsessed with finding a sea route to India. He wanted to avoid the Muslim control of the eastern Mediterranean and the routes connecting India to Europe. In 1454, Pope Nicholas V gave him permission to navigate the sea to the distant shores of the Orient, specifically as far as India, to spread Christianity and counter Islamic influence.
summary.6: Prince Henry of Portugal, also known as the 'Navigator', was obsessed with finding an ocean route to India and circumventing Muslim domination of the eastern Mediterranean. Pope Nicholas V gave him permission to navigate to India in an attempt to spread Christianity and fight Islamic influence. However, Prince Henry died before his dream could become a reality. In 1497, Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them by an imaginary line in the Atlantic, allowing Portugal to claim and occupy everything to the east of the line, paving the way for Portuguese incursions into the waters around India.
summary.7: Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them by an imaginary line in the Atlantic. Portugal could claim everything to the east of the line while Spain could claim everything to the west. This allowed the Portuguese to explore the waters around India. In 1497, Portuguese ships set out for India and arrived in May 1498, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope in Africa.
summary.8: In May 1498, Vasco Da Gama arrived in Calicut with three ships and a Gujarati pilot named Abdul Majid. The Hindu ruler of Calicut, the Zamorin, welcomed them as he believed they were traders. However, Arab traders were worried about the Portuguese gaining control of the Malabar Coast where they had a good business.
summary.9: The Arab traders were worried about the Portuguese taking over their business on the Malabar Coast. In the past, many different groups had traded in the Indian Ocean, but they all followed certain rules and no one tried to control everything. The Portuguese were different - they wanted to be the only ones making money from the trade. Vasco da Gama stayed in India for three months.

For centuries, the trading system in the Indian Ocean had had numerous participants—Indians, Arabs, Africans from the east coast, Chinese, Javanese, among others—but these participants had acted according to some tacit rules of conduct and none had sought overwhelming dominance though all were in it for profit. story.0: Long ago, in the land of India, there were many different periods of history. Some were ancient, some were medieval, and some were modern. But history is like a never-ending story, with one period flowing into the next. When the Europeans first arrived in India, it marked the beginning of the modern period. But to understand this, we must go back to a time before even the great Mughal Empire was established.
story.1: After the Roman Empire fell, the Arabs became powerful in Egypt and Persia. This made it harder for Europeans to trade with India and get things like spices and precious stones. Then, in 1453, the Ottoman Turks took over Constantinople and made it even harder to trade. So, Europeans started looking for a new way to reach India by sea.
story.2: When the Ottomans were gaining power, Constantinople fell in 1453. The Arabs controlled the trade routes to India, making it difficult for Europeans to get their hands on spices, silk, and precious stones. The Europeans wanted to find a direct sea route to India, so they could trade without intermediaries. They were inspired by the Renaissance and had made great progress in ship-building and navigation.
story.3: As Europe advanced in ship-building and navigation, they longed to explore the unknown corners of the East. The region's economic development was also booming with improved farming techniques and increased meat supply, leading to a demand for spices and luxury goods from the East.
story.4: As Europe grew richer, people wanted more fancy things from the East. Venice and Genoa were too small to explore or fight the Ottoman Turks. But the north Europeans helped Portugal and Spain with money and men, and the Genoese gave them ships and knowledge. Portugal was also leading the fight against Islam and exploring like the Genoese.
story.5: Prince Henry of Portugal, also known as the ‘Navigator’, really wanted to find a way to get to India by sea. He didn't like that the Muslims controlled all the routes to India. The Pope gave him permission to sail to India in 1454, so he could spread Christianity and fight against the Muslims.
story.6: Prince Henry of Portugal, also known as the Navigator, wanted to find a way to reach India without going through Muslim-controlled areas. Pope Nicholas V gave him permission to sail to India and spread Christianity. Sadly, Prince Henry died before he could achieve his goal. Later, Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them, with Portugal claiming everything to the east of an imaginary line in the Atlantic. This allowed Portugal to explore the waters around India.
story.7: After Prince Henry's death, Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them. Portugal could claim everything to the east of an imaginary line in the Atlantic, while Spain could claim everything to the west. This allowed the Portuguese to explore the waters around India. In 1487, Bartholomew Dias sailed around the Cape of Good Hope and believed he had found the sea route to India. Ten years later, Portuguese ships set out for India and arrived in May 1498 after almost 11 months.
story.8: After Bartholomew Dias found a sea route to India, Portuguese ships set out for India in 1497. They arrived in May 1498, led by Vasco Da Gama and a Gujarati pilot named Abdul Majid. The Hindu ruler of Calicut welcomed them, but Arab traders were worried about the Portuguese taking over their business on the Malabar Coast.
story.9: The Arab traders were worried about the Portuguese coming to the Malabar Coast. They had been trading there for a long time with others from different places. Everyone followed certain rules, but the Portuguese wanted to be in charge and make all the money. Vasco da Gama stayed in India for three months.
